text: - Hello everybody.
My name is Girish Keshav
and I am a solution architect at AWS.
Welcome to a short talk

on automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation
with AWS Shield Advanced.
AWS Shield Advanced establishes a baseline
for all AWS WAF enabled resources
to detect layer seven attacks.
Minimum baseline time is 24 hours
after enabling Shield Advanced
and for higher accuracy
AWS recommends a 30 day baseline.
A combination of significant deviations
from this traffic baseline

and Route 53 health checks
are flagged as a DDoS event.
If a DDoS event occurs,

not only one needs to
manually build AWS WAF rules
that isolate the malicious traffic,

but also deploy the rules
using AWS WAF console
or by using APIs.
This would be followed by

testing the rules effectiveness
against the attack.
AWS Shield Advanced customers
can utilize the Shield response team

to create such AWS WAF rules
or rely on their own expertise.
Overall, the process can consume time,
thereby increasing the time it takes
to mitigate a DDoS attack.
This is where automatic application layer
DDoS mitigation feature comes in handy.

Now let's take a look at
how this feature works.

Automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation
is a set of capabilities
included for all Shield Advanced customer.
This will enable Shield to automatically
mitigate malicious web traffic

that threatens to impact
application availability.
This feature automatically checks
for attacks against normal traffic,
creates tests and deploys AWS WAF rules

to mitigate layer seven DDoS
events on behalf of customers.

There is flexibility
to enable this feature
in count or block mode.

Count mode enables customers
to check the room groups
and rules being created during an attack
but not block traffic.
Block mode, on the other hand

will block identified malicious
traffic during an attack.
Please note at the time of this recording,

automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation

is available only on research
type Amazon CloudFront
and application load balancer.

Now, let's see what
happens during an attack.
Traffic that significantly deviates

from the established
Shield Advanced baseline
will be flagged as a potential DDoS event.
After an event is detected,

AWS Shield Advanced will
attempt to identify a signature
based on offending request patterns.
If a signature is identified,
AWS WAF rules will be created

to mitigate attack traffic
with that signature.
The rules will then be added
to Shield-Managed rule group.

Please note that
auto-mitigation rule group

requires 150 WCUs or
web-based cell capacity units.

Customers can choose whether
the rules are deployed
in count mode to observe and test
or block mode to block the attack.

Customers can also
create CloudWatch alerts

based on when the requests
are being blocked or counted.

Customers also have
the option to intervene

and change the action
between count or block mode

or disable the feature
entirely at any given time.

Shield Advanced will automatically
remove any AWS WAF rules

after it has determined that
the attack has fully subsided.

With that, let me you how
to enable this feature
in AWS console.
After logging into the AWS console,
search shield in the search bar

and from the dropdown
click on WAF and Shield.
Before we dive into the main topic
let me quickly show you a web ACL
that I have already created for this demo,
which we will utilize

while configuring automatic
mitigation feature.
On the left hand side under AWS WAF,
click on Web ACL.
Select the corresponding region
and click on the name of the web ACL.
Click on the rules tab

and as you can see I have
two rules currently in place.
One is an AWS managed rule
and the second one is a rate based rule.

We will revisit this section
at the end of this demo.
Let's get started

with automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation.
On the left hand side expand AWS Shield
and click on getting started.
Please note, as mentioned before
to get the benefits of Shield Advanced

you must subscribe to
an annual subscription.

This page displays global
activity detected by AWS shield
and various other important information
related to your account.
For the purpose of this demo
we will add a new resource to be protected
with Shield Advanced.
You can also alternatively

add automatic application
layer mitigations
to resources that are already protected.
Click on add resource to protect.
In the following page

select the resource type
that you wish to protect.

In our case, it is
application load balancer

so we will uncheck the
rest of the options.
Click on load resource type.
From the list of resources
select the ALB you wish to protect.

In the next section,
add any relevant tags.

Click on protect with
Shield Advance to continue.
Next associate any web ACLS
that you have created for this setup.
This is where automatic application layer

mitigation rule group will
be created and placed.

Please note AWS Shield
will not create a web ACL
automatically during an attack.
Select the ALB

and from the drop down select
the corresponding web ACL.
Any rate-based rules in the ACL
are listed here for our reference.
The next section is where we can configure

automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation.
Here we are presented

with three options for
automatic mitigations.
First option is keep current settings.

This option will preserve
any previous settings

for automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation.
The second option is enable.
This option will enable

automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation.
Upon selection of this option,
an additional dropdown is presented
to choose a WAF rule action.
We can either choose count or block mode
for traffic that matches
a rule placed in automatic mitigation.

We recommend keeping
rule action in count mode
until your application establishes
a consistent traffic pattern.
The third option is disable.
If already enabled,

you can disable the feature
by choosing this option
while modifying a protected resource.

Note, this section can be
changed at any time in future

to any of the three option
even during a DDoS attack.
Click next to continue.

In the next page we can
optionally configure

Route 53 health check
based DDoS detection.

AWS highly recommends you
to enable this feature

for additional data point
to improve the accuracy
of network-layer and transport-layer
event detection and mitigation,
as well as web request flood detection.
For the purpose of this demo

I have already
pre-configured a health check
and will choose it from the dropdown.
Click on next to continue.

Next section is to optionally
configure SNS topic

to get notified in case
of a DDoS detection
or any rate-based alarms.

For this demo, we will not
set up the SNS settings.
Click next to continue.

The final section is to
review all previous settings.
As we have chosen count mode

in automatic application
layer DDoS mitigation,
a warning in red is shown to indicate
that this is only to monitor

and no action will be
taken in case of an attack.
Click on finish configuration.

This concludes enabling
automatic application layer
DDoS mitigation feature.
Finally, we can now navigate to web ACL
and check on the ACL that was associated
with application load balancer

to see that we have now
an additional rule group
called shield mitigation rule group.
On the left hand side
click on web ACL to continue.
Click on the name of the web acl.
Go to the rule

and you can see that there is
shield mitigation rule group
associated with web ACL.
In case of a DDoS attack

Shield Advance will
automatically add rules

in count or block mode
based on initial settings
into this rule group.
As and when the attack subsides
the rules are removed automatically.

Please note, a user cannot
modify this rule group directly.
This concludes the control walkthrough.
Here are some best practices
for using automatic mitigation feature.

If you're using AWS Firewall
Manager to centrally configure

and manage Shield and
WAF security policies
across multiple accounts,
then it is recommended that
all Shield automatic mitigation features
should be configured in Firewall Manager
and not Shield Advanced directly.
If multiple endpoints are supported,
always choose the one that is first point
or parameter of the attack.

For example, if your workload
involves Amazon CloudFront
and ALB, it is recommended to apply

automatic application layer
DDoS mitigation feature

on CloudFront as that would be
the parameter of DDoS attack.
It is recommended to test
and observe the feature in count mode
before moving it to block mode.

Do not delete shield
mitigation rule group in WAF.
If you do, you disable the protection

provided by Shield Advance
automatic mitigation

for every resource that is
associated with the web ACL.
Lastly, enable Route 53 health checks

and set up CloudWatch alarms
for efficient reporting.

Lastly, please check out the
links in the video description
for further reading.
Thank you for your time

and happy cloud computing
from all of us at AWS.
